newsitem.title: UK: UK asks for two-year Social Chapter delay - paper.
newsitem.headline: UK asks for two-year Social Chapter delay - paper.

text.p: Britain's Labour government has asked for a two-year minimum transition period before implementing the European Union's Social Chapter on workers' rights, a newspaper reported.

The Independent said in its Friday edition that although a senior British source said there was no question of "delaying tactics", Whitehall officials said a formal request had been made for a transition period to give companies time to prepare for the costly changes.
The newspaper noted that other countries had been given a two-year leeway before directives had been implemented and Britain was merely asking for the same transition period.
Adopting the Social Chapter will mean firms have to set up consultative works councils and give three months unpaid leave to parents after the birth of a child.
Prime Minister Tony Blair will, however, formally reverse the former Conservative government's opt-out during a two-day Amsterdam summit next week.

Early action can also be expected on a separate Working Time Directive, giving employees the right to refuse to work more than 48 hours per week and an entitlement of three weeks' paid annual leave, the Independent said.
